Severity: 1
Risk factor: None

finding.id: 21157_SN.8 Lockout Accounts After 3 Failures - Checking if 'deny' is correctly set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "SN.8 Lockout Accounts After 3 Failures - Checking if 'deny' is correctly set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth" : [FAILED] A system policy of locking out an account that fails several successive authentication attempts is an industry best practice and is easily implemented in this Benchmark. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 11, pp 117-118. - error message: The file "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" does not contain ^account[\s\t]+required[\s\t]+pam_tally2.so[\s\t]+deny=2[\s\t]+no_magic_root reset
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_SN.8 Lockout Accounts After 3 Failures - Checking if 'onerr' is correctly set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "SN.8 Lockout Accounts After 3 Failures - Checking if 'onerr' is correctly set in /etc/pam.d/system-auth" : [FAILED] A system policy of locking out an account that fails several successive authentication attempts is an industry best practice and is easily implemented in this Benchmark. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 11, pp 117-118. - error message: The file "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" does not contain ^auth[\s\t]+required[\s\t]+pam_tally2.so[\s\t]+onerr=fail[\s\t]+no_magic_root
Severity: 3

finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "13.0 Remove CIS Benchmark Hardening Backup Files." : [PASSED] When benchmark remediation is complete, remove the backup files as they will likely have insecure contents and/or permissions/ownerships. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 13, page 111. Checking if /etc/cron.d-preCIS exists on the system.
Severity: 1

finding.id: 21157_11.5 Restrict permissions to 0644 on /usr/local/share/man/
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "11.5 Restrict permissions to 0644 on /usr/local/share/man/" : [PASSED] Reduce the excessive permissions on man pages and system documentation files down to 0644. These are stable files, provided by the Operating System and package vendor that users have only read access to. The CIS benchmark remediation executes 'go-w' so we are only checking for mask 022 as a result. If this check fails, run 'find /usr/share/doc/ -type f -perm /go+w -print' at the command-line of the system in question in order to determine which files have wrong permissions. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 11, page 107. Checking if the mask is correct for usr/local/share/man/*/
Severity: 1

finding.id: 21157_9.11 Limit Access To The Root Account From su - Checking if 'auth required /lib/security/$ISA/pam_wheel.so use_uid' is uncommented in /etc/pam.d/su.

Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "9.11 Limit Access To The Root Account From su - Checking if 'auth required /lib/security/$ISA/pam_wheel.so use_uid' is uncommented in /etc/pam.d/su." : [PASSED] Ideally, only members of the wheel group should have the ability to 'su' to root. Enforcing this standard adds an additional layer of security to your system. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 9, pp 92-95.

These files, if found and determined to not be system-critical, should be removed. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 9, pp 89-90.

finding.id: 21157_9.7 No User Dot-Files Should Be World-Writable - Checking that user dot files do not have the world-write bit set.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "9.7 No User Dot-Files Should Be World-Writable - Checking that user dot files do not have the world-write bit set." : [PASSED] World-writable user configuration files (dot files like .bash_profile or .bashrc) may enable malicious users to steal or modify other users' data or to gain another user's system privileges. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 9, page 89.
Severity: 1

finding.id: 21157_8.10 Only Enable syslog To Accept Messages If Absolutely Necessary - Checking if 'SYSLOGD_OPTIONS' are set appropriately.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "8.10 Only Enable syslog To Accept Messages If Absolutely Necessary - Checking if 'SYSLOGD_OPTIONS' are set appropriately." : [FAILED] Relevant only if your machine is a log server or needs to receive Syslog messages via the network from other systems. If this machine is not a log server this query should be commented out. Otherwise, configuration is required, set the 'loghost' & 'mydomain.com' variables in the 'expect' statement to appropriate values. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 8, page 84. - error message: The file "/etc/init.d/syslog" could not be found
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_8.6 Restrict Root Logins To System Console - Checking if only vc/1-11, tty1-6 and console are present in /etc/securetty.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "8.6 Restrict Root Logins To System Console - Checking if only vc/1-11, tty1-6 and console are present in /etc/securetty." : [PASSED] Root logins should occur locally from the system console and never via anonymous means. Standard user login should always precede root access to provide an audit trail. NOTE: CIS has commented out tty1-6 to deny root from the physical TEXT console. You may need to uncomment these, depending on organizational needs and exception allowances. NOTE: Serial consoles ttyS0,1 are commented out as CIS recommends adding them only if used. You may need to uncomment these, depending on organizational needs and exception allowances. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 8, pp 80-82.
Severity: 1

finding.id: 21157_8.4 Restrict at/cron To Authorized Users - Checking if /etc/cron.deny does not exist.

Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "8.4 Restrict at/cron To Authorized Users - Checking if /etc/cron.deny does not exist." : [FAILED] The cron.allow and at.allow files are a list of users who are allowed to run the crontab and at commands to submit jobs to be run at scheduled intervals. cron.deny and at.deny should be removed and cron/at.allow should be restricted to the root user. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 8, pp 79-80. - error message: The file /etc/cron.deny exists
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_8.9 Restrict NFS Client Requests To Privileged Ports - Checking if the insecure keyword is not present in /etc/exports.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "8.9 Restrict NFS Client Requests To Privileged Ports - Checking if the insecure keyword is not present in /etc/exports." : [FAILED] The secure option should be set for all entries in /etc/exports. This option tells the NFS server process to ignore NFS client requests not originating from the privileged port range (< 1024) ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 8, page 83. - error message: The file "/etc/exports" could not be found

finding.id: 21157_8.5 Restrict Permissions On crontab Files - Checking if /etc/crontab permissions are OK.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "8.5 Restrict Permissions On crontab Files - Checking if /etc/crontab permissions are OK." : [FAILED] The system crontab files are accessed only by the cron daemon (which runs with superuser privileges) and the crontab command (which is set-UID to root). Allowing unprivileged users to read or (even worse) modify system crontab files can create the potential for a local user on the system to gain elevated privileges. Note: this check may generate a false-positive from 'pre-CIS' backup files. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 8, page 80.
File : /etc/crontab Remote value: owner: root group: root mode: 0644 uid: 0 gid: 0 uneven permissions : FALSE Policy value: owner: root group: root mask: 7377 uneven permissions : TRUE
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_8.4 Restrict at/cron To Authorized Users - Checking if /etc/at.allow permissions are OK.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "8.4 Restrict at/cron To Authorized Users - Checking if /etc/at.allow permissions are OK." : [FAILED] The cron.allow and at.allow files are a list of users who are allowed to run the crontab and at commands to submit jobs to be run at scheduled intervals. cron.deny and at.deny should be removed and cron/at.allow should be restricted to the root user. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 8, pp 79-80. - error message: The file /etc/at.allow does not exist
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_8.1 Remove .rhosts Support In PAM Configuration Files.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "8.1 Remove .rhosts Support In PAM Configuration Files." : [PASSED] Rhosts_auth is used in conjunction with the r-commands which implement weak authentication. Rhosts support should be disabled in the PAM configuration files by removing the rhosts_auth entry(ies). ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 8, page 77. Checking if rhost_auth is NOT present in any file under /etc/pam.d.
Severity: 1

finding.id: 21157_7.9 Disable USB Devices. 'modprobe.conf'
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "7.9 Disable USB Devices. 'modprobe.conf'" : [FAILED] USB devices are a known attack vector and should be disabled from server usage in most cases. Additionally, bootable USB configuration should be disabled (see Benchmark section 7.2 for remediation steps.) ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, page 75. Checking that usb-storage is disabled in /etc/modprobe.conf. - error message: The file "/etc/modprobe.conf" does not contain ^[s]*install\s+usb-storage\s
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_7.7 Find Unauthorized SUID/SGID System Executables
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "7.7 Find Unauthorized SUID/SGID System Executables" : [FAILED] Unauthorized SUID/SGID executables can indicate compromise and should be removed when found. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 71-74. Checking for unauthorized SUID/SGID files. - error message: The following files are SUID or SGID :
/bin/passwd owner: root, group: root, permissions: 4711
/usr/bin/man owner: root, group: man, permissions: 2551
/usr/bin/dotlockfile owner: root, group: mail, permissions: 2751
/usr/bin/expiry owner: root, group: root, permissions: 4711
/usr/bin/cdcc owner: root, group: root, permissions: 4511
/usr/bin/dccproc owner: root, group: root, permissions: 4511
/usr/bin/fusermount owner: root, group: root, permissions: 4711
/usr/bin/cdrecord owner: root, group: root, permissions: 4711
/usr/bin/readcd owner: root, group: root, permissions: 4711
/usr/bin/netselect owner: root, group: wheel, permissions: 4711

finding.id: 21157_6.2 Turn On Additional Logging For FTP Daemon.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "6.2 Turn On Additional Logging For FTP Daemon." : [FAILED] Red Hat Enterprise Linux logs connections and all files transferred in vsftpd, however, CIS requires that all commands sent to the server be logged. Note: the checks for this benchmark item will pass if vsftp configuration is not found on this server. Checking that xferlog_std_format is set to 'NO' in '/etc/vsftpd/vsftpd.conf' ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 6, page 62. - error message: The file "/etc/vsftpd/vsftpd.conf" does not contain ^xferlog_std_format=[nN][oO]$
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_4.3 Ensure sendmail is only listening to the localhost, If Possible - Check DAEMON setting.

Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "4.3 Ensure sendmail is only listening to the localhost, If Possible - Check DAEMON setting." : [FAILED] Unless the scanned system is a mail server configured to receive mail from remote hosts, sendmail should be configured to accept mail on port 25 only from localhost. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 42 - 43. Checking that DAEMON is set to 'NO' in /etc/sysconfig/sendmail - error message: The file "/etc/sysconfig/sendmail" could not be found
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_3.2 Configure TCP Wrappers and Firewall to Limit Access - Check /etc/hosts.deny contents.
finding.finding_txt:
Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "3.2 Configure TCP Wrappers and Firewall to Limit Access - Check /etc/hosts.deny contents." : [FAILED] Typically, there is no need to allow unlimited network access to a host. CIS recommends implementation of TCP Wrappers / firewall as means of preventing this access. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 31-33. Checking that hosts.allow and hosts.deny are set to limit remote access appropriately. Change the values in this audit to match your corporate policies. Should pass if /etc/hosts.allow is configured to allow localhost access to '192.168.' and /etc/hosts.deny is configured to deny all other access. Should pass if /etc/hosts.allow is configured to allow localhost access and /etc/hosts.deny is configured to deny unlimited access. - error message: The file "/etc/hosts.deny" could not be found
Severity: 3

finding.id: 21157_2.3 Configure SSH - Checking if Port is set to 22 and not commented for server.

finding.id: 21157_2.3 Configure SSH - Checking if Protocol is set to 2 and not commented for client.

Unix Compliance Checks
Description: "2.3 Configure SSH - Checking if Protocol is set to 2 and not commented for client." : [FAILED] OpenSSH, the popular and free SSH protocol standard, is extremely important for security hardening. Despite the advancement security-wise of SSH over other older protocols for console access and file transfer, a number of important steps should be taken to ensure that SSH has been secured properly. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 2, pp 24-25. - error message: The file "/etc/ssh/ssh_config" does not contain ^[\s\t]*Protocol[\s\t]
Severity: 3

Authenticated Check: OS Name and Installed Package Enumeration This plugin gathers information about the remote host via an authenticated session.
Plugin output: It was possible to log into the remote host using the supplied asymetric keys The output of "uname -a" is : Linux agent 2.6.37-gentoo-r4 #1 SMP Sun May 22 22:03:36 CEST 2011 x86_64 AMD Athlon(tm) 64 Processor 3000+ AuthenticAMD GNU/Linux
The remote Gentoo system is : Gentoo Base System release 2.0.3
Local security checks have been enabled for this host.
Description: This plugin logs into the remote host using SSH, RSH, RLOGIN, Telnet or local commands and extracts the list of installed packages.
If using SSH, you should configure the scan with a valid SSH public key and possibly an SSH passphrase (if the SSH public key is protected by a passphrase).
Solution: n/a
Severity: 1
Risk factor: None
